If I were to ever get to go see this place, I'd be more curious about seeing what the joints and surfaces between some of those tight fitting rocks looked like. The smooth rocks with rounded edges and perfect joints look to have been almost cast, similar to our concrete. At the very least, I'm betting those rocks were chemically softened or the joints were agglomerated from natural stone chips or powder. Since some of those rocks aren't perfectly fitted and some are, it looks like there might have been a natural chemical softener like citric acid, acetic acid, or some blend that was used later in the construction from cruder fitting stones to soften and improve the joints. Anyway, that's what I'd be most interested in finding out if I were ever to go see this place and others like it in South America. I'd be slyly looking under a stone or two and confirming a theory or two on construction technique.

The floating heads and hats and things come up because the picture is made up of smaller high res pictures all put together. Think of them as pixels, but using a separate high res photo in each one left to right, top to bottom. So the left to right images are close in time frame, but the camera had to complete that row before moving down to the next row. So top to bottom, things and people may have moved in the time it took the camera to get to the photo below where their head was before.
Destin is at the top of the first set of staircase leading up to the peak, on the left side of the picture.

I would have recommended a sharper lens. The 100-400 L IS is a nice, flexible lens, but it's not known for it's ultimate sharpness. If you needed that much reach, the 400 F4 would have been a good choice. The 300 F2.8 L IS would have also given you much better sharpness, but does cost a lot more. The 300 F2.8 or 400 F4 stopped down to F11 is darn near pixel sharp. "Resolution" is more than just cramming as many photos together as possible.

Floating body parts are due to the method of composing using gigipan technology.  Photos taken at high zoom of very small areas creates huge data layers that allow you to zoom in and effectively allow you to examine the photo in max zoom detail.  However a moving object will not be in the same place as the gigipan matrix is photographed, causing bodily disassociation - this however is painless to the victims, or so I'm told....
The floating head and the 2 floating torsos are in the same area, the upper left corner of the picture, or the far left area of the Machu Pichu structure.

I'm guessing this is a retaining wall and thus the lower section needs gereater strength, the middle needs less than the lower and the upper section needs less than the middle.

I noticed there are 3 techniques of ashlar masonry in the long straight wall Destin mentioned.  The bottom portion uses the largest stones and motar-less construction and uneven horizontal joints which is the strongest way to do ashlar masonry.  The middle section uses mortar-less construction where the horizontal joints do line up which is not as strong but is faster.  The top section employs ashlar with mortar joints which is even weaker but even faster to build.

a panoramic photo is made by taking a bunch of images that will slightly overlap and then are "stitched" together to make a massive canvas. obviously time passes as the separate pictures are being taken so people will move and only parts of them will be in the picture. the head by destin near the top of the picture is an example. him being in it twice i'm sure wasn't planned, either and that's another consequence of time passing between pictures. also think i found a guy in a pink shirt 3 times

In case you're wondering, there is more than one floating head in the picture. There are also two floating torsos, a girl with no legs, and one girl on top of someone else's legs. Also, someone left their purse unattended just above Destin... not too smart!

It's caused by the person being there when one photo was taken, but by the time the photo above/below was taken the person had moved.  When the photos were stitched together, there's part of a person in one, but no person in the other.
He actually appears to be in it twice, once near the floating head and a little lower than that sittng down. You can see how it's him seeing as both have the same close on.

Disembodied heads are cool. ;) It happens when you do multi-level panorama, and the head gets caught in the higher level pass, then when you do lower level pass the person is gone. Best to just clone them out. Pretend you're a grim reaper. ;)

When you stitch together many images in a grid like this to make one large image, there is a significant delay between when the photos in one row are taken and when the photos in the next row are taken. This causes some odd things to happen to non-stationary objects (like people) when the program puts all the images together. So an image taken that just includes someones head could be stitched with another image below it containing something entirely different where the body of the person was.

That doesnt make sense though..it makes sense in museums and in certain circumstances like conventions where, if footage is taken, people can actually lose money from exposure.. but what profit is taken away from the people if someone does take a photo and sell it? I still dont understand..especially because its such a well known place already..theres already been thousand if not millions of profesional photographs taken by outside sources..what could be lost or gained from this regulation?

It happened because these huge images actually are composed of many smaller images. In the video you can see, that they actually took 1920 pictures (2:50) and then stitched them together on the PC(3:05). 
And due to the fact, that you cannot take 1920 pictures at exactly the same time with only one camera, you have people moving between shots. They might appear in 2 images at the same time, or only with their head in one, then they move away before the next row "hits" their body.
